results.title: Living with riverboats
results.brief_description: Mark Smith talks about his enduring passion for riverboats which all began when he worked on the restoration of the Paddle Steamer Gem.

results.title: Living with forests
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Education Dept. Curriculum Branch, Stephen Skok and Ian Toohill
results.brief_description: Living with forests: The future of Leadbeater’s forest is the subject of a local enquiry. The viewer is asked to imagine that you are a member of the local community and give your views.

results.title: Living with dust
results.brief_description: Made for the Audio Visual Communications Centre, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co., the film presents causes of dust in nature and industry and gives methods of controlling these conditions. It tells how different dusts affect workers and what can be done to protect them.

results.title: Living with a giant
results.brief_description: Reviews the dominance of Canada by the giant nation on her border, the United States of America. The film explores how the proximity of the US has impacted on Canada’s trade and business, recreation and independent way of life. Includes footage of a meeting between John F. Kennedy and the Prime Minister of Canada.

results.title: Living way out
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton and Philip Robertson
results.brief_description: Depicts life in Shay Gap, a remote mining town in Western Australia. Residents and a social planner speak of the problems of isolation - stress, boredom and loneliness - and how they attempt to resolve them.

results.title: Living traps
results.brief_description: A study of the more common carnivorous plants. Examines the traps of the bladderwort, butterwort, pitcher plant and members of the sundew family, including the venus flytrap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.description: A study of the more common carnivorous plants. Examines the traps of the bladderwort, butterwort, pitcher plant and members of the sundew family, including the venus flytrap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 155
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Coal and oil for fuel will one day run out, even the fuel for conventional nuclear reactors is in short supply. Yet every day the sun pumps massive amounts of energy into the earth and its atmosphere. Looks at some of the proposed new methods for harnessing the enormous natural flow of renewable energy: heat from the sun; power from the wind; photosynthesis; hydrogen; solar cells.
